channel.name: How do I check the account verification key in a method?

messages.content: `acc1.body.update.verificationKey.value.hash` is the wrong place to look. in general, you can't just read onchain values off your account update. the account update describes an _update_ and not the current state of the account in the ledger
for onchain values, you generally use preconditions and there is none for the vk hash: https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/writing-a-zkapp/feature-overview/on-chain-values#account-reference

however, I think there is a partial workaround for the vk hash. on an account update authorized with a proof, the current vk hash is commited to on `body.authorizationKind.verificationKeyHash`

but note that the protocol **only checks that this is the right hash if** `authorizationKind.isProved = true`.

i.e., to provably get a current account's vk hash in a method, you have to create a valid proof with it as well, i.e. call a zkapp method on that account
thank you I got the verification key but it not the same key than contract.compile method, I will choose an other way to do that
Finally I will create a sub account with the verification key directly from the contract, I hope is manipulation resistant
my code is not definitive I need to check if the newPair wasn't already created
You can use receipt chain if you really need this.
Or you can use a token account
What do you mean by receipt chain ?
The receipt chain hash is a merkle list of all commands applied to an account.
You can recurse through it to get the last update that set the vk
I don’t think it’s practical to do in O1JS though
I’m using pickles directly in ocaml
I’d recommend just using a token account though
What do you need this for?
I create token pair for a dex, I need to have unique pair and be sure the pair was created with the correct contract, to prevent from malicious activities
Use a token account
This is the exact use case for custom tokens.
Custom tokens are contrary to what you think not actually about tokens.
yeah it's what I did like the secon code I shared
const update = AccountUpdate.createSigned(_newAccount, this.tokenId);
Yep
It'd be the same if the account update is created from a method call
Btw your code has a bug where you use && on a Bool

😂 thank you I need to use the method in bool class probably

When I created pool with deploy method and compate the hash to pool.compile, is not the same
Deploy method is not a zkapp method, it doesn't create a proof
I pass the public key of this contract to the method

your idea of a factory method looks good to me.

the only thing I'm worried about is that it will fail as soon as you push more than 32 actions, because that's the hard-coded number of actions that `reduce()` processes.
(We're working on a config option to make `reduce()` use recursive proofs under the hood, with that it would never break in that way)
I don't get what the intention of using `this.tokenId` here is

This is not the way to create a sub-account ?

So reducer is bad idea if I need to handle more than 32 pair, I need to use a merkle tree maybe

> So reducer is bad idea if I need to handle more than 32 pair, I need to use a merkle tree maybe
@Youtpout you should try `Experimental.OffchainState`! It's much nicer than using `MerkleTree` directly
It also uses actions under the hood

> This is not the way to create a sub-account ?
no, to create an owned account you have to use the token id _derived_ from the parent, not _the same_ token id as the parent
`this.tokenId` would just be the default (MINA) token
you're looking for `this.deriveTokenId()` (only available on `TokenContract`, because token contracts have specific security considerations)

I'm going to try a simpler solution to solve this problem
my main problem is the account update limit, for the first liquidity provider there are 8 account updates and so it crashes, I'd rather do this in several steps, rather than try to go through offchain solutions for the moment
my factory will inherit from it so
`OffchainState` only relies on actions atm, just so you know - you don't need to set up your own state storage
but it does complicate the flow, because you always have to settle the state
also I already use the 8 slot of the contract, I will need a extra account to store it

ok I see. offchain state needs 2 onchain account fields. however, you can store any number of extra fields _inside_ the offchain state, so potentially you could move some of your current onchain fields into offchain
OffchainState is fundamentally trustful, no?
Or does it use events
no
it completely creates the state from actions, and fully proves that they were sent to the zkapp account
not trustful at all
you should read my PR descriptions @Las 😄
Oh that’s great
I thought events would be more suited for this though

in offchainstate i can create any mapping I want ?
like I declare 10 map properties in OffchainState ?
Yes
If I understand after each offchain storage update I need to settle the proof
How implement it on test, I got this error :

@Youtpout don't have time to look into your error, but there's a detailed test in the o1js repo if you want a reference: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/src/lib/mina/actions/offchain-contract.unit-test.ts

messages.content: you can launch the test with command npm run testfactory in folder contracts
Pool contract is not initialized here since you deploy manually.
This error disappers when Pool is initialized.
What do you mean ? even if I don't use this code anymore, the solution could be interesting
I was investigating https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1684. I figured out your code doesn't work because you don't initialize the Pool contract when they are generated in the Factory contract.
